leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.5] r 10.5 The various methods of service (cf SCR Part 9, rules 3 and 4; DCR Part 8, rules 3, 9 and 12; LCR Part 7, rules 3, 9 and 12)

leg:heading.title: The various methods of service (cf SCR Part 9, rules 3 and 4; DCR Part 8, rules 3, 9 and 12; LCR Part 7, rules 3, 9 and 12)

p.text: Subject to these rules, a document may be served on a person:
by means of personal service, or
by posting a copy of the document, addressed to the person:
to the person’s address for service, or
if the person is not an active party, to the person’s business or residential address, or
by leaving a copy of the document, addressed to the person:
at the person’s address for service, or
if the person is not an active party, at the person’s business or residential address,
with a person who is apparently of or above the age of 16 years and apparently employed or residing at that address, or
in the case of service on a corporation, by serving the document on the corporation in any manner in which service of such a document may, by law, be served on the corporation.
[subr (1) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[19], effective 15 August 2005]
In the case of a person having an address for service that is a solicitor’s office address, service of a document on the person may also be effected:

if the notice advising the address for service includes a DX address, by leaving a copy of the document, addressed to the solicitor, in that DX box at that address or in another DX box for transmission to that DX box, or
if the notice advising the address for service includes a fax number, by faxing a copy of the document to that number, or
if the notice advising the address for service includes an electronic service address, by transmitting an electronic copy of the document to that address.
[subr (2) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[8], effective 7 December 2007]
Unless the contrary is proved, the time at which a document is taken to have been served is:
in the case of a document that is left in a DX box in accordance with subrule (2)(a), at the end of the second day following the day on which the copy is so left, or
in the case of a copy of a document that is faxed in accordance with subrule (2)(b), at the end of the first day following the day on which the copy is so faxed.

See clause 13 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000 as to when an electronic copy of a document is taken to have been delivered to an electronic mail address. See also Division 3 of this Part as to how personal service is to be effected.
[Note am Amendment 38 of 2010 s 3(5), effective 15 October 2010]
Legislation cited in [10.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.14(3).
(NSW) Interpretation Act 1987 s 76(1).
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 160.

Posting the document to, and leaving a copy of the document at, the person’s address are alternative means of service under the rule: cf Jiminez and Sons v Owen [1883] WN 232. Where a party has an address for service, documents that are sent to another address are not validly served unless it is shown that they actually came to the attention of the person concerned: White v Weston [1968] 2 QB 647; [1968] 2 All ER 842. If a party has no address for service, the party's proper address for service is their last known place of abode. The requirement that the address be at a person's “business or residential address” is consistent with the general position that an address is a place at which written communications can be delivered to the person concerned. Consistent with that proposition, service by delivery to a post office box may be a valid service — depending on the precise terms of the statutory requirement for service: Macrae v St Margaret's Hospital (1999) 19 NSWCCR 1; [1999] NSWCA 381; BC9907034 . A mere forwarding address does not constitute an address for the purpose of effecting ordinary service in accordance with the present rule (Willowgreen Ltd v Smithers [1994] 2 All ER 533 at 537; [1994] 1 WLR 832 at 836), but service so effected might be confirmed by the court under r 10.14(3) in circumstances where steps have been taken to bring the document to the notice of the person concerned. Where documents are sent by prepaid post they are presumed to have been delivered four working days after posting unless the contrary is shown: Interpretation Act 1987 s 76(1) ; Evidence Act 1995 s 160 . The presumption does not arise if the documents are returned undelivered: Australian Trade Commission v Solarex Pty Ltd (1987) 78 ALR 439 . Nor does it arise if the postal address is incorrect: Wallville Pty Ltd v Liristis Holdings Pty Ltd (2001) 10 BPR 19,089; [2001] NSWSC 894; BC200106396 ; and see a note on this case at (2002) 76 ALJ 19 (incorrect postcode).

level.toc-caption: [10.5.10] Service in the precincts of the court

heading.title: Service in the precincts of the court

p.text: There may be circumstances where the service of process within the precincts of the court will amount to contempt if the service of the process might tend to obstruct the administration of justice or otherwise interfere with a litigant's ability to conduct proceedings in the court: Cole v Hawkins (1738) Andr 275; 95 ER 396 . Subject to that qualification, service may be effected in the precincts of the court: Baldry v Jackson [1976] 1 NSWLR 19 (statement of claim served on the footpath outside the court after having given evidence); Re Tole (1933) 50 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 216; Poole v Gould (1856) 156 ER 1133 (originating process served on a person attending to answer a subpoena); R v Jones; Ex parte McVittie [1931] 1 KB 664 (judgment summons served on a plaintiff waiting for his case to be called on); Re O'Sullivan; Ex parte O'Sullivan v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1995) 57 FCR 145; 129 ALR 295 (service in premises adjacent to, and providing internal access to, the court building).

level.toc-caption: [10.5.15] Time of service — service on Sunday

heading.title: Time of service — service on Sunday

p.text: Proceedings may be served at any hour of the day: Murray v Stephenson (1887) 19 QBD 60 ; Upton v Mackenzie (1822) 1 Dow & Ry KB 172. Historically, service could not be effected on a Sunday: Oulton v Radcliffe (1874) LR 9 CP 189. Now s 3 of the Sunday (Service of Process) Act 1984 permits any court process to be served on any Sunday except one that coincides with Christmas Day.
Legislation cited in [10.5.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 35.8.

Service may be proved by filing an affidavit of service in accordance with UCPR r 35.8 . The requirements for proof of service have always been plain, even in the absence of a rule: Warringah Shire Council v Magnusson (1932) 49 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 187. The affidavit should state, in the case of personal service, the date and place of service, the manner in which service was effected and how the deponent identified the person served. The affidavit should contain a sufficient description of, but should not annex copies of, the documents served. In order to prove service by post, it is necessary that the evidence of one or more witnesses establish: that the document said to have been served was placed inside an envelope, that the envelope had the correct name and address written or typed on its face, that a postage stamp or franking of the necessary amount was affixed to the envelope and that the envelope so addressed and stamped or franked, was physically deposited in the post either at a post office or by being dropped into a post box for the reception of mail articles: Brown v Bluestone Property Services Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 869; BC201005449 at [12]–[13] ; Northumbrian Ice Cream Co Ltd v Breakaway Vending Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1216; BC200609566 at [12]–[13] ; see also Smirski v Macander [2010] NSWSC 929; BC201006065 at [13]–[14] ; French Consulting Pty Ltd v Donald [2011] NSWSC 584; BC201104685 at [28]–[30] . Where the evidence is less than ideal, there may still be a proper basis for concluding that service by posting has actually occurred based on inferences from proved facts: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Clear Blue Developments Pty Ltd [2010] FCA 1223; BC201008500 at [24]–[34] (based on inferences from the use of the expression “prepaid post” service was established).

level.toc-caption: [10.5.25] Service where receipt not in issue

p.text: Legislation cited in [10.5.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.5(2)(b).

heading.title: Service where receipt not in issue

p.text: Many cases have rejected the need for formality of service where receipt of a document is established: Pino v Prosser [1967] VR 835 at 838 (“remarkable to the point of absurdity” not to regard receipt as service); Howship Holdings Pty Ltd v Leslie (No 2) (1996) 41 NSWLR 542; 133 FLR 307; BC9603984 ; Parklands Blue Metal Pty Ltd v Kowari Motors Pty Ltd [2004] 1 Qd R 140; [2003] QSC 098; BC200301686 . Consequently, an admitted receipt by fax of the acceptance of an offer of compromise constitutes service even if the recipient party’s solicitor provided a formal fax address for the purpose of what is now r 10.5(2)(b) : Mohamed v Farah [2004] NSWSC 482; BC200403298 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.6] r 10.6 Service in accordance with agreement between parties (cf SCR Part 9, rule 9; DCR Part 8, rule 15; LCR Part 7, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Service in accordance with agreement between parties (cf SCR Part 9, rule 9; DCR Part 8, rule 15; LCR Part 7, rule 15)

p.text: In any proceedings, any document (including originating process) may be served by one party on another (whether in New South Wales or elsewhere) in accordance with any agreement, acknowledgment or undertaking by which the party to be served is bound.

In relation to the service of an originating process in proceedings on a claim for possession of land, the agreement, acknowledgement or undertaking referred to in subrule (1) must be made after the originating process is filed but before it is served.
[subr (1A) insrt Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[3], effective 10 July 2009]
Service in accordance with subrule (1) is taken for all purposes (including for the purposes of any rule requiring personal service) to constitute sufficient service.
Legislation cited in [10.6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Real Property Act 1900 s 74N.

Parties may agree on a special mode of service in place of that provided by the rules: British Controlled Oilfields Ltd v Stagg (1921) 127 LT 209; Reversionary Interest Society Ltd v Locking [1928] WN 227; Mondial Trading Pty Ltd v Interocean Marine Transport Inc (1985) 65 ALR 155; BC8501059 . It is common for Lloyds insurers to nominate a local person to accept service and service on that person will be regarded as good service: Tharsis Sulphur Co v Société des Metaux (1889) 58 LJQB 435; 60 LT 924 and Montgomery Jones & Co v Liebenthal & Co [1898] 1 QB 487. Similarly, this rule has been held to authorise service of a statement of claim on the defendant's third party insurer, where that insurer had indicated its willingness to accept service and had assumed the conduct of the defence pursuant to an authority contained in the insurance policy: Samarni v Williams [1980] 2 NSWLR 389. But the court must be satisfied that the agreement relied on did relate to the service of documents concerning judicial proceedings. Consequently, neither an agreed address for service in a standard form of contract of sale of land (Gaggain v Lemari (2000) 10 BPR 18,381; (2002) NSW ConvR ¶56-002 ; [2000] NSWSC 856; BC200005015 ), nor the commercial use of a business address with telephone and fax numbers (Molins plc v GD SpA [2000] 1 WLR 1741 (service by fax)), can be relied on as an agreement for the purpose of the present rule. However, a summons to remove a caveat may be served at the address for service of notices shown on the caveat: Re Drinkwater (1929) 46 WN (NSW) 202 ; and see Real Property Act 1900 s 74N .

The rule contemplates a situation where the parties have entered into a formal agreement that contains specific provisions for the service of any process relating to the subject matter of the agreement. But agreements as to service may arise on other occasions where, either in relation to specific proceedings or as a matter of putting in general administrative procedures, informal agreements are made about the manner in which service may be effected. In such cases, service in accordance with the arrangements will be regarded as valid: Kenneth Allison Ltd v AE Limehouse & Co [1992] 2 AC 105; [1991] 4 All ER 500 (instructions to an employee to accept service); Ditfort v Temby (1990) 26 FCR 72; 97 ALR 409 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.7] r 10.7 Notice given or served by court (cf SCR Part 9, rule 14)

leg:heading.title: Notice given or served by court (cf SCR Part 9, rule 14)

p.text: Subject to any order of the court, any notice or other document that is required to be given to or served on any party by the court, or by any officer of the court, is taken to have been given or served if served in any manner in which a document not requiring personal service may be served under this Part.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.8] r 10.8 Service of defence by court (cf LCR Part 9, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Service of defence by court (cf LCR Part 9, rule 3)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in the Local Court.
[subr (1) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
When filing a defence, whether in person, by post or by use of an authorised DX system, a party must lodge additional copies of the defence for service on each of the other active parties.
On receiving such copies, an officer of the court:
must mark each copy with the date of acceptance of the document, and
must return one copy to the party by which it was filed, and
must cause the remaining copies to be served on each of the other active parties.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.9] r 10.9 Service of process on defendant operating under unregistered business name (cf SCR Part 64, rule 3; DCR Part 46, rule 2; LCR Part 35, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Service of process on defendant operating under unregistered business name (cf SCR Part 64, rule 3; DCR Part 46, rule 2; LCR Part 35, rule 2)

p.text: This rule applies to any proceedings against a person in respect of anything done or omitted to be done by the person in the course of, or in relation to, a business carried on under an unregistered business name.
For the purposes of any such proceedings, any document may be served on the defendant, whether sued in his or her own name or under the unregistered business name:
by leaving it with a person who is apparently engaged in the business, and apparently of or above the age of 16 years, at any place at which business is carried on under that name, or
by sending it by post, addressed to the defendant, to any place at which business is carried on under that name,
whether or not the place concerned is within New South Wales.
For the purposes of any such proceedings:
service of a document in accordance with subrule (2) is taken to constitute personal service, and
the place at which the document is left, or to which the document is sent by post, is taken to be the place of service of the document, and
in the case of a document sent by post, the document is taken to have been served at the end of 7 days after the day on which it was sent.
This rule does not limit any other law with respect to the service of documents.

level.toc-caption: [10.9.5] Commencement of proceedings using a business name

p.text: Legislation cited in [10.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.20, r 7.21.

heading.title: Commencement of proceedings using a business name

p.text: UCPR r 7.20 contains provisions regulating the commencement of proceedings against a defendant carrying on business under an unregistered name. The defendant must respond in their own name: see r 7.21 . The plaintiff must then amend the documents in the proceedings to substitute the defendant’s own name: see r 7.22.

level.toc-caption: [10.9.10] The place where the “business is carried on”

heading.title: The place where the “business is carried on”

p.text: A person carries on business at any place where a partner or manager is in control carrying on the business. The business must be actually carried on: Union Bank of Australia Ltd v Lohmann [1916] VLR 530 . If the person in control is a mere agent, whether business is being carried on will depend upon the extent of the agent's authority. The firm carries on business if the agent is authorised to conclude contracts: La Bourgogne [1899] AC 431 ; Dunlop Pneumatic Tyre Co Ltd v Actien Gesellschaft Fur Motor Und Motorfahrzeugbau Vorm Cudell and Co [1902] 1 KB 342 ; Okura and Co Ltd v Forsbacka [1914] 1 KB 715 , but it does not carry on business at that place if the agent’s authority is limited to taking orders and merely transmitting them to the person: Baillie v Goodwin (1886) 33 Ch D 604 ; Grant v Anderson (1892) 1 QB 108. Nor is it sufficient that the place is one to which the person often resorts for the purpose of transacting business: Heinemann v Hale and Co [1891] 2 QB 83 ; Singleton v Roberts and Co (1894) 70 LT 687; National Bank v Perez and Co [1891] 1 QB 304.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.10] r 10.10 Service of process on defendant operating under registered business name (cf SCR Part 64, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Service of process on defendant operating under registered business name (cf SCR Part 64, rule 3)

p.text: This rule applies to any proceedings against a person carrying on business under a registered business name in respect of anything done or omitted to be done by the person in the course of, or in relation to, business carried on under that name.
For the purposes of any such proceedings, any document may be served on the defendant, whether sued in his or her own name or under the registered business name:
by leaving it with a person who is apparently engaged in the business, and apparently of or above the age of 16 years, at any place at which business is carried on under that name, or
by sending it by post, addressed to the defendant:
to any place at which business is carried on under that name, or
to the address for service of any person in whose name the business name is registered under the Business Names Act 2002, whether or not the place concerned is within New South Wales.
For the purposes of any such proceedings:
service of a document in accordance with subrule (2) is taken to constitute personal service, and
the place at which the document is left, or to which the document is sent by post, is taken to be the place of service of the document, and
in the case of a document sent by post, the document is taken to have been served at the end of 7 days after the day on which it was sent.
This rule does not limit any other law with respect to the service of documents.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.11] r 10.11 Service of process on partner in limited partnership (cf SCR Part 64, rule 3A)

leg:heading.title: Service of process on partner in limited partnership (cf SCR Part 64, rule 3A)

p.text: This rule applies to any proceedings against a partner in a limited partnership (within the meaning of Part 3 of the Partnership Act 1892) in respect of anything done or omitted to be done by any person in the course of, or in relation to, a business carried on by the partnership.
For the purposes of any such proceedings, any document may be served on the defendant, whether sued in his or her own name or under the firm-name of the partnership:
by leaving it with a person who is apparently engaged in the business, and apparently of or above the age of 16 years, at the registered office of the partnership, or
by sending it by post, addressed to the firm-name of the partnership, to the registered office of the partnership.
For the purposes of any such proceedings:
service of a document in accordance with subrule (2) is taken to constitute personal service, and
the place at which the document is left as referred to in subrule (2)(a), or to which the document is sent as referred to in subrule (2)(b), is taken to be the place of service of the document, and
in the case of a document sent as referred to in subrule (2)(b), the document is taken to have been served at the end of 7 days after the day on which it was sent.
This rule does not limit any other law with respect to the service of documents.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.12] r 10.12 Service of process on person under legal incapacity (cf SCR Part 63, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Service of process on person under legal incapacity (cf SCR Part 63, rule 15)

p.text: This rule applies to any proceedings in which a document is required to be served personally on a person under legal incapacity.
Personal service on a person under legal incapacity may not be effected otherwise than in accordance with this rule.
If the person under legal incapacity has a tutor in the proceedings, the document may be served on the tutor.
The document may be served on any person (including the person under legal incapacity) whom the court may, before or after service, approve.
If the person to be served is a minor and has no tutor in the proceedings, the document may be served:
on the person, but only if the person is aged 16 years or more, or
on a parent or guardian of the person, or
if the person has no parent or guardian, on a person with whom he or she resides or in whose care he or she is.
if the person has a manager in respect of his or her estate, on the manager, or
if the person does not have a manager, on a person with whom he or she resides or in whose care he or she is.
[subr (6) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[6], effective 8 October 2009]
Subject to subrule (8), a document served pursuant to this rule must be served in the manner required by these rules in relation to documents of the same kind.
In addition to any other service required by these rules:
a judgment or order requiring a person under legal incapacity to do, or refrain from doing, any act, and
a notice of motion for the committal of a person under legal incapacity, and
a subpoena addressed to a person under legal incapacity,
must be served personally on the person.
Subrule (8) does not apply to an order for interrogatories or for discovery or inspection of documents.
Legislation cited in [10.12.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 7.13, 7.18.
As to proceedings involving persons under legal incapacity, see UCPR Pt 7 Div 4 ( rr 7.13 – 7.18 ).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.13] r 10.13 Acceptance of service by solicitor (SCR Part 9, rule 7; DCR Part 8, rules 6 and 7; LCR Part 7, rules 6 and 7)

leg:heading.title: Acceptance of service by solicitor (SCR Part 9, rule 7; DCR Part 8, rules 6 and 7; LCR Part 7, rules 6 and 7)

p.text: If a solicitor notes on a copy of:
any originating process, or
any other document required or permitted to be served in any proceedings, but not required to be personally served,

that he or she accepts service of the document on behalf of any person, the document is taken to have been duly served on that person on the date on which the note is made or on such earlier date of service as may be proved.
Legislation cited in [10.13.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 16.1–16.10.

Acceptance of service by a solicitor does not, however, imply any undertaking to enter an appearance. If such an undertaking is given, the solicitor is bound by the undertaking irrespective of whether it was given without authority (Darley v Hyman (1894) 15 LR (NSW) L 189; Squires v Weeks (1893) 9 WN (NSW) 122), or the client alters the solicitor’s instructions: Re Kerly, Son and Verden [1901] 1 Ch 467 . However, the court retains a power to release the undertaking in appropriate circumstances: Simpson v Brereton [1964] VR 332 . If no appearance is filed, the provisions of the rules relating to default judgment may be invoked in the ordinary way: see UCPR rr 16.1–16.10 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.14] r 10.14 Substituted and informal service generally (cf SCR Part 9, rules 10 and 11; DCR Part 8, rules 5 and 16; LCR Part 7, rules 5 and 16)

leg:heading.title: Substituted and informal service generally (cf SCR Part 9, rules 10 and 11; DCR Part 8, rules 5 and 16; LCR Part 7, rules 5 and 16)

p.text: If a document that is required or permitted to be served on a person in connection with any proceedings:
cannot practicably be served on the person, or
cannot practicably be served on the person in the manner provided by law,
the court may, by order, direct that, instead of service, such steps be taken as are specified in the order for the purpose of bringing the document to the notice of the person concerned.
An order under this rule may direct that the document be taken to have been served on the person concerned on the happening of a specified event or on the expiry of a specified time.

If steps have been taken, otherwise than under an order under this rule, for the purpose of bringing the document to the notice of the person concerned, the court may, by order, direct that the document be taken to have been served on that person on a date specified in the order.
Service in accordance with this rule is taken to constitute personal service.

An application for substituted service should be supported by affidavit and include a minute of the proposed order (substituted service often involves service by post and/or service upon an agent of the defendant). The affidavit should show why personal service is not practicable and include details of any unsuccessful attempts that have been made to obtain information and effect service: Syndicate Mortgage Solutions Pty Ltd v El-Sayed [2009] NSWSC 207; BC200901942 at [6] (mere reliance on ASIC searches insufficient — electoral and directory searches desirable). The affidavit should also refer to the terms of the proposed order for service and indicate whether the proposed mode of substituted service is likely to bring the proceedings to the notice of the person to be served. Thus, the affidavit or minute filed with the application should specify the desired mode of substituted service, for example, by forwarding a copy of the process in question to a named relative or friend or business acquaintance of the defendant; by forwarding a copy thereof to his or her last known place of residence or business; by advertising twice in a daily newspaper, etc.

The court's power to direct substituted service depends on the impracticability of effecting ordinary service in accordance with the rules. This is an impressionistic criterion that is neither satisfied by evidence of inconvenience nor demands evidence of impossibility: Alstrom Ltd v Sirakas [2010] NSWSC 669; BC201004252 at [40].

Apprehended delay will not ordinarily suffice to justify an order for substituted service: Ricegrowers Co-Operative Ltd v ABC Containerline NV (1996) 138 ALR 480; BC9603412 (proposed foreign party — already legally represented in related proceedings within the jurisdiction — no relevant “impracticability” sufficient to authorise substituted service); Syndicate Mortgage Solutions Pty Ltd v El-Sayed [2009] NSWSC 207; BC200901942 (insufficient evidence (of relevant searches or inquiries) to establish impracticability of ordinary service).

Orders for substituted service may be justified by justified apprehensions that a party may evade service or leave the jurisdiction: Alstrom Ltd v Sirakas [2010] NSWSC 669; BC201004252 at [43]–[46]; or dispose of assets that are the subject matter of the proceedings: Conan Doyle's Will Trusts Harwood v Fides Union Fiduciaire [1971] Ch 982; [1971] 2 All ER 1377 .
Legislation cited in [10.14.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 ss 15, 20.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 11.1, 11.12.

Substituted service may be ordered where the person is amenable to service under ss 15 and 20 of the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth): Western Suburban and Notting Hill Permanent Benefit Building Society v Rucklidge [1905] 2 Ch 472 ; Rosenbaum v Rosenbaum [1926] VLR 280; (1926) 32 ALR 255 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Sweeney [2000] NSWSC 1249; BC200008339 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Sweeney (No 2) (2001) 38 ACSR 743; [2001] NSWSC 477; BC200103587 . But substituted service is not a means of overcoming any territorial limits on the jurisdiction of the court: Laurie v Carroll (1958) 98 CLR 310; 32 ALJR 7 . If the person is neither within Australia nor otherwise able to be served in accordance with UCPR rr 11.1 – 11.12 at the time the proceedings are commenced, an order may not be made for substituted service: Laurie v Carroll , above. Thus, if a defendant leaves the jurisdiction before the commencement of the proceedings, there is no foundation for an order for substituted service (unless Pt 11 applies), even if the departure was for the purpose of evading service: Myerson v Martin [1979] 3 All ER 667 ; Laurie v Carroll ; not following Porter v Freudenberg [1915] 1 KB 857 at 887 . However, if the defendant is within the jurisdiction at the time of filing of the originating process and subsequently leaves either with knowledge of the commencement of proceedings, or for the purpose of evading service, substituted service may be ordered: Sheahan v Joye (1995) 57 FCR 389 ; see also Gate Gourmet Australia Pty Ltd (in liq) v Gate Gourmet AG [2002] NSWSC 727; BC200204587 (provisional order made for substituted service where defendant was outside the jurisdiction).

level.toc-caption: [10.14.20] Bring to the notice of the person to be served

heading.title: Bring to the notice of the person to be served

p.text: The court must be satisfied that the method of substituted service sought by the plaintiff is one which will in all reasonable probability, if not certainty, be effective to bring knowledge of the proceedings to the defendant: Porter v Freudenberg [1915] 1 KB 857 at 889 (Porter v Freudenberg was subsequently disapproved by the High Court in Laurie v Carroll (1958) 98 CLR 310; 32 ALJR 7 , but not on this point). The significance of the requirement that the proposed mode of service should be one which is reasonably likely to bring the proceedings to the notice of the defendant was indicated in Chappell v Coyle (1985) 2 NSWLR 73, where Yeldham J held that the rule did not justify an order for substituted service on the defendant's insurer where it was neither intended nor likely that service on the insurer would bring notice of the proceedings to the attention of the nominal defendant: see also Gurtner v Circuit [1968] 2 QB 587; [1968] 1 All ER 328. This decision departed from a number of cases in which substituted service of this kind had been permitted: Kevin v Schmeisze [1964] QWN 51 ; Lawford v Hosth (1974) 5 ALR 57; McCann v Parsons (1954) 93 CLR 418; [1955] ALR 14 ; Hunt v Molk (1976) 11 ALR 288 ; Foxe v Brown (1984) 58 ALR 542; 59 ALJR 186; BC8400466 .
Legislation cited in [10.14.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.11(b), r 36.16.

Unless it is set aside under UCPR r 12.11(b) , substituted service in accordance with an order made under the present rule is valid even though it is shown that the proceedings do not in fact come to the notice of the defendant: Grice v Grice [1930] St R Qd 261 ; Watt v Barnett (1878) 3 QBD 183. Nevertheless, any judgment or order that has been made by default or in the absence of a party, may be varied or set aside in the exercise of the power conferred by: UCPR r 36.16 .

level.toc-caption: [10.14.30] Steps taken otherwise than under an order under this rule

p.text: Legislation cited in [10.14.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.14(3).

heading.title: Steps taken otherwise than under an order under this rule

p.text: The purpose of the rule is to grant a general discretion to confirm service whenever the court is satisfied that appropriate notice of the proceedings has been given. The discretion ameliorates the effect of some of the narrow distinctions drawn in the decided cases as to whether a particular mode of service was carried out in literal compliance with the requirements of the rules. Informal service may be confirmed if the court is satisfied that the contents of the originating process were in fact brought to the knowledge of the defendant or its advisors: see r 10.14(3) ; WFM Motors Pty Ltd v Maydwell (NSWSC, Bryson J, 23 April 1993, unreported, BC9301698); Vista Capital Developments Pty Ltd v Talmarc Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 935; BC200807957 at [14] per Brereton J (evidence of correspondence between legal representatives in relation to the proposed orders).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.15] r 10.15 Substituted and informal service of originating process in proceedings for possession of land (cf SCR Part 9, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Substituted and informal service of originating process in proceedings for possession of land (cf SCR Part 9, rule 5)

p.text: This rule applies to originating process that is required to be served on a defendant in connection with proceedings for the possession of land but that cannot be served on the defendant without undue delay or expense.
The court may order that the plaintiff may serve the originating process on the defendant by affixing a copy of the originating process to a conspicuous part of the land.
An order under subrule (2) may direct that the originating process be taken to have been served on the defendant on the expiry of a specified time.

If a copy of the originating process has been affixed to a conspicuous part of the land, otherwise than under an order under subrule (2), the court may order that the originating process be taken to have been served on the defendant on a date specified in the order.
A party may apply for an order under this rule without filing or serving notice of motion.
An application for an order under this rule must be supported by an affidavit by the applicant that includes:
a statement as to the applicant’s knowledge of the defendant’s whereabouts, and

a statement as to any communications that have occurred between the applicant and the defendant since the cause of action in the proceedings arose (including any communications by telephone, fax or electronic mail).
[subr (5A) insrt Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[7], effective 8 October 2009]
Service in accordance with this rule is taken to constitute personal service.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.16] r 10.16 Service by filing (cf SCR Part 9, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Service by filing (cf SCR Part 9, rule 12)

p.text: If in any proceedings any document is required or permitted to be served on:
a person who is in default of appearance, or
a person who has entered an appearance but is not an active party in the proceedings,
the filing of the document is taken to have the same effect as service of the document on the person unless the court orders otherwise.
This rule does not apply to any document that is required to be served personally.
Legislation cited in [10.16.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 9.6.
This rule does not apply to the service of a cross-claim: see UCPR r 9.6 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.17] r 10.17 Service of injunctions (cf SCR Part 9, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Service of injunctions (cf SCR Part 9, rule 15)

p.text: If the court grants an interlocutory injunction, the party may serve notice of the injunction by letter signed by or on behalf of the registrar.

This rule provides one way in which notice of the injunction may be served. It is also common for the court to grant leave to give notice of an injunction by telephone or facsimile. In addition, instead of service of a document signed by the registrar, some judges prefer to direct service of a copy of the judge's notes. Where service is to be carried out by service of a notice signed by the registrar, the moving party should attend the registry with a copy of the judge's notes and the court file. The documents will be prepared in the registry and issued to the party for transmission to, or service on, the parties to be served.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.18] r 10.18 Service at address for service in other court or tribunal (cf SCR Part 9, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Service at address for service in other court or tribunal (cf SCR Part 9, rule 8)

p.text: If:
a decision is given or a case is stated in proceedings before any judicial officer or other person (the proceedings below), and
a party to the proceedings below (the subject party) has an address for service in New South Wales for the purposes of those proceedings at the office of a solicitor (the address below), and
proceedings (not being proceedings in relation to punishment for contempt) arising out of the proceedings below are commenced in the court (the new proceedings), and
the plaintiff in the new proceedings has not received notice that the address below has ceased to be applicable,

documents, including the originating process, may be served on the subject party at the address below, until the subject party has an address for service in the new proceedings, as if the address below were the subject party’s address for service in the new proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.19] r 10.19 Waiver of objection to service (cf DCR Part 8, rule 5(3))

leg:heading.title: Waiver of objection to service (cf DCR Part 8, rule 5(3))

p.text: A party who files a document in reply to a document alleged to have been served on that party is taken to have waived any objection to the fact or manner of service unless he or she files and serves notice of the objection together with the document so filed.

level.toc-caption: [10.19.5] Deemed service — the effect of a notice of appearance

p.text: Legislation cited in [10.19.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 63.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.11.

heading.title: Deemed service — the effect of a notice of appearance

p.text: An appearance may be entered even if the originating process has not been served: Oulton v Radcliffe (1874) LR 9 CP 189; The Gniezno [1967] 2 All ER 738 ; Pioneer Concrete (North Coast) Pty Ltd v Bennett [1972] Qd R 544 . A party who enters an appearance waives any irregularity in the manner of service. Even if no formal appearance is entered, a party who attends court and argues the merits of the proceedings will usually be treated as having waived any irregularity in the manner of service: Boyle v Sacker (1888) 39 Ch D 249 ; Carver v de Robillard [2006] FCA 1041; BC200606161 (court rules specifically provided that attendance gave rise to deemed personal service); Secombe v Bate (1888) 9 LR (NSW) 161 (attendance by a legal representative for the purpose of objecting to jurisdiction is sufficient proof of personal service): see further CPA s 63 and its accompanying annotations. Any challenge to the validity of service may be made by motion under UCPR r 12.11 without the entry of an appearance.
